sentences.english: Once upon a time Wisahketchahk got ready and went forth.
Then he saw a buffalo.
It started to run away.
“Wait a bit, Little Brother!” he said to it.
Then the buffalo stopped.
“Why, you are all hot!” he said to it.
Then he felt its belly.
He stabbed it from there with his knife.
Then he cut pieces from it.
He lay there, having placed the pieces of meat along the ground, intending to eat.

sentences.original: êkwah ayih oskanah cîkaham, pimiy êh-osîhtât;
sentences.text: êkwa ayih oskana cîkaham pimiy ê-osîhtât
sentences.english: And the bones he broke, to make fat;
he put it into the bladder.
Then he went to the river.
He saw some muskrats.
“Come here, Little Brothers,” he said to them;
“I want this stuff to get cool.”
He gave them the fat.
He tied it to the tail of one.

sentences.original: sipwêhtêw sîpîhk wacask, pimiy anima ê-tahkatiniyik, êh-papâmiskât.
sentences.text: sipwêhtêw sîpîhk wacask pimiy anima ê-tahkatiniyik ê-papâmiskât
sentences.english: Then the muskrat went off into the river, so that the fat cooled off as it swam about.
“Don't call out and frighten me,” said the muskrat.
Then Wisahketchahk watched it from the brush.
From the bank of the stream he whistled at the muskrat and frightened it.

sentences.original: tapasîw wacask; koskopayihtâw ôma pimiy; êkwah sîpîhk pimâhotêw.
sentences.text: tapasîw wacask koskopayihtâw ôma pimiy êkwa sîpîhk pimâhotêw
sentences.english: The muskrat fled; it spilled the fat; the fat floated on the water.

sentences.original: êkwah wîsahkêcâhk pimipahtâw sîpiy ôm âyi ê-sâ-sôpahtahk pimiy, sîpîhk.
sentences.text: êkwa wîsahkêcâhk pimipahtâw sîpiy ôma ayi ê-sâ-sôpahtahk pimiy sîpîhk
sentences.english: Then Wisahketchahk ran and lapped up the fat from the river.
Angry was Wisahketchahk.
“Mortal men will call this fat 'foam.'
It was I who created this earth;

sentences.original: kîhkîhk ka-nakiskâtin, wacask; kihkîhk ka-nakiskâtn, niy âskiy kâ-kî-osîhtâyân!
sentences.english: in spite of all, I shall meet you, Muskrat, I who created this earth!”
Then Wisahketchahk went away.
Then he saw a big forest.
Now it was winter; he was very cold.
He saw some tents;
children were playing there.

sentences.original: âstam, nisîm, itêw, tân ânim âyi okimâw wîkih ?
sentences.english: “Come here, Little Brother,” he said to one; “Which is the chief's tent?”
The boy pointed it out to him, and he went there.
He entered.
The man there called, “Come in, my elder brother!”
He sat down opposite the door.
He was given wild quinces to eat, in the form of pemican.
“Do not undress, Brother;
early in the morning we move camp.”
In spite of the warning, Wisahketchahk undressed.
He hung up his clothes to dry.
Then he lay down.
It was very cold.
Early in the morning a great many partridges flew up.
Wisahketchahk was sleeping on the snow.
And it was very cold.
On a tree hung those clothes of his.
Wisahketchahk was almost frozen to death.
He was angry; he arose;
those partridges had moved camp.
Wisahketchahk was angry.
“I shall look for the partridges, I who created the world!”
Then Wisahketchahk went away from there.
hen, at one time, as he was walking along, in summer, what was that? --
some young partridges he saw in a nest.
“What is your name, young partridges?”
“Why, you have just called us by name!”
Ever do people have two names.
For instance, I: Wisahketchahk, Born-of-Old.”
Then those partridge-chicks: “Little Winged Startlers we are called.”
They angered Wisahketchahk by these words;
he muted upon the nest.
Then he departed.
Then Wisahketchahk departed.
Then the old partridges came to their nest.
They were angry that their young had been befouled.
They went away.
They made an assembly.
Many of them set out.
By a brook they lay in wait for Wisahketchahk;
on both banks of the little stream they sat.
Then Wisahketchahk came walking along.
Soon he saw the brook.
Four times I shall run at this brook.
Then I shall jump across.”
Then he walked off; he walked back;
he took a running start, heading for the brook.
At the very point of jumping across, he halted.
Again he walked back.
Again he took a running start.
“Now I shall jump across,” he said.
So now he made for it.
ust as he jumped, up went the partridges.
He fell square into the water.
He lost his tobacco-pouch in the water.
In time the water carried him to the bank.
He lay there by the water's edge.
hen he got up; he looked for his tobacco-pouch.
He could not find it at all.
Then once, as he looked that way, it lay there in the water.
He looked for it.
He went into the water.
He could not get hold of it.
He merely clawed up mud whenever he made a grasp.
All day he was there in the brook.
At last he went back to the bank.
He was tired.
He was angry at having lost his tobacco-pouch.
Then at one time he looked that way; he saw it hanging up aloft.
He took it.
“Bah, the dirty dogs!” he said of them; “They surely have angered me!”
He went away from there.
He went from place to place.
Then he saw a great many ducks.
The ducks started to flee.
“Wait a bit, Little Brothers!” he called to them.
“No, Big Brother.
You mean to kill us.”
Wisahketchahk carried something on his back.
He deceived them.
Then he went away.
There was a lake; it was a very big lake.
He went thither.
“Big Brother,” said a duck, “what are you carrying on your back?”
“The Shut-Eye Dance.”
“Do give us a dance.”
“It is hard, Little Brothers.”
“Please, Big Brother!”
“Very well!”
Then he built a lodge.
He assembled all kinds of ducks and geese.

sentences.original: sôskwât êkwah pîhtokêw, êkwah sîsîpak misahkamik, ê-wîh-nîmihitocik.
sentences.text: sôskwât êkwa pîhtokêw êkwa sîsîpak misahkamik ê-wî-nîmihitocik
sentences.english: Then at once he entered, and all the ducks were to dance.
“You will close your eyes for this dance of yours.”
“Yes”, said the ducks.
Then he began to sing.
Then the ducks danced; but they had their eyes closed.
Then Wisahketchahk arose;
he set about killing those ducks by stabbing their little heads.

sentences.original: kêkâc êh-mêscihât, pêyak awah apisîsisiw napatê piko pasakwâpiw.
sentences.text: kêkâc ê-mêscihât pêyak awa apisîsisiw napatê piko pasakwâpiw
sentences.english: When he had nearly finished all of them, one little fellow held only one eye shut.
He saw him.
“Wisahketchahk is killing us!”
He ran away; so did one other, the diver-duck.

sentences.original: nîso pikoh is-tapasîwak; pimâtisiwak nîso pikoh.
sentences.text: nîso piko isi-tapasîwak pimâtisiwak nîso piko
sentences.english: Only two of them thus escaped; only two got away with their lives.
Then he laughed much.
“I did not bring any dance at all.
I was very hungry.
Truly, foolish are the ducks.
Now I shall have plenty to eat.”
Then he built a fire.
He set his food to cook.
Then he went away.
“First I shall take a walk.
Afterwards I shall eat.”
He left his roasts.
As he was walking, he saw a fox.
“Hey, stop a bit, Little Brother!” he said to him;
“We shall have a race.

sentences.original: awiyak nakasiwêcih, sîsîpah kahkiyaw ta-môwêw, itêw.
sentences.english: Whichever wins will eat all the ducks,” he said to him.

sentences.original: êkwah mahkêsîs : namoya! niwîsakêyihtên niskât; namoya, wîsahkêcâhk.
sentences.english: Then the fox: “No. I have a sore leg; no, Wisahketchahk.”
“I shall tie some stones to my leg.
That way you will outrun me.”
“Very well,” said the fox.
Then Wisahketchahk tied some stones to his leg.
Then they started off at a great rate.

sentences.original: namoya kîh-kisiskâhtêw wîsahkêcâhk; osâm kosikwatiwak asiniyak.
sentences.text: namôya kî-kisiskâhtêw wîsahkêcâhk osâm kosikwatiwak asiniyak
sentences.english: Wisahketchahk could not go fast; the stones were too heavy.
And the fox limped.
They ran round a hill.

sentences.original: âkawâyihk êh-ihtât mahkêsîs, mitoni sôhki pimipayiw.
sentences.text: âkawâyihk ê-ihtât mahkêsîs mitoni sôhki pimipayiw
sentences.english: When the fox got out of sight behind it, he ran very well.
He went and ate up all the ducks.
He ate all except the feet.
Then he ran  away.
At nightfall Wisahketchahk arrived.
He pulled forth one duck.
“I have cooked him too long,” he said.
He pulled out another; finally all of them.
“I am overdoing my roasts a bit,” he said.
Then he understood.
He was angry at the fox.
“It is I created the earth!
I will find you!”
He went from there; he looked for the fox.
hen at one time, as he walked about, he found him sleeping in the tall grass.
“What shall I do to him?
If I club him, I shall spoil the hide.
I shall have it for a tobacco-pouch.
I had better stifle him by building a fire round him.”
All around he set fire to the grass.
The flames spread.
When the blaze came close, the fox jumped to his feet.
He was glad when the other jumped to his feet.

sentences.original: namoya nânitaw kikîh-itâmon, kâ-kitamwacik nisîsîpimak, yahâh, yahâh! itêw.
sentences.english: “You cannot escape anywhere, you who ate all my ducks, yahaw, yahaw!” he said to him.
Then he waited for the fox.
He laughed, thinking, “I am certainly killing him with this fire!”
But when the fire subsided, there was no fox.
sentences.footnote: LB:  Not “bad grammar” or simplification for my benefit:  the Sweet Grass people regularly use {nama kîkway} with animates, as, {nama kîkway ayôskanak}: “There aren't any (more) raspberries.”

sentences.english: He had run away.
“Miserable foul-breathed fool!
Where could you escape?
All the more surely will I find you!” he said of him.
He pursued him.
Then once, as he walked along, he heard loud and repeated laughter.
He went into the brush at either side:  nothing.

sentences.original: âsa mna sipwêhtêw; kêtahtawê kâ-wâpamât picikîskisîsah êh-yâ-yakonamiyit oskîsikosiyiwah, êh-âh-akociwêpinamiyit sakâhk, êkwah êh-koskwâskopitamiyit, kâwi mânah êh-tâpiskopayiyikih.
sentences.text: âsay mîna sipwêhtêw kêtahtawê kâ-wâpamât picikîskisîsa ê-yâyakonamiyit oskîsikosiyiwa ê-âh-akociwêpinamiyit sakâhk êkwa ê-koskwâskopitamiyit kâwi mâna ê-tâpiskopayiyiki
sentences.english: He went on again; soon he saw some jays pulling out their eyes and tossing them so they caught in the brush, and shaking the bushes, whereupon the eyes would spring back into place.
“What is the idea of this, Little Brother?”
“Because I have a headache we are doing this.”
“Give it to me.
My head greatly torments me.”
“No.
It is difficult.”
“Please give it to me.
I have an everlasting pain in my  head.”
“Oh, no!”
“Do take pity on me, Little Brothers.
Right now I feel the old pain coming back in my head.”
“Very well.
I will give you four doses.

sentences.original: têstikwânêyini, kâya wiya nôhtaw, mêyâkwâm, nistêsê.
sentences.english: When you have a headache, not at any other time; don't forget, Big Brother!”
They gave him the power to pull out his eyes four times.
“Thank you, Little Brothers.
I shall be having a cruel headache.”
Then he went from there.
He had not gone far; he began to groan.
“There is my head tormenting me as usual!”
He went into the brush.
He pulled out both his eyes.
He threw them onto a bush.

sentences.original: êkwah mistikw êh-ocipitât, kâwi ô-pahkihtiniyiwa oskîsikwa.
sentences.text: êkwa mistikw ê-ocipitât kâwi ôh-pahkihtiniyiwa oskîsikwa
sentences.english: Then, when he pulled at the bush, his eyes fell from it, back into place.
He set out again.
He did not walk far.
Again he was in pain.
“My head!”
Again he stepped into the brush.
There he pulled out his eyes.
He threw them so that they caught and hung.
But then, though he tugged at the bush, they were not there.
That fox had stolen Wisahketchahk's eyes.
So now he was blind.
Then Wisahketchahk kept tugging at the tree all day.
Then he went away.
He was blind.

sentences.original: êkw âwa mahkêsîs mistik otinam; nakiskawêw; cahkâpahwêw.
sentences.text: êkwa awa mahkêsîs mistik otinam nakiskawêw cahkâpahwêw
sentences.english: And the fox took a stick; he went to meet him; he jabbed him in the sockets of his eyes.
Hum,” he said, “I am getting snagged in my eye-holes,” and walked on.
Then the fox left him alone.
Then at one time he bumped into something.
“What sort of tree are you?” he asked it.
“Poplar.”
“That is not the kind I want.”
He set out again.
Again he bumped.
“What are you called?”
“I am a spruce.”
“That is the kind I want.”
Then he sought rosin; he found it.

sentences.original: êkwah osîhtâw oskîsikwah êwakonih ohci pikiwah.
sentences.text: êkwa osîhtâw oskîsikwa êwakoni ohci pikiwa
sentences.english: Then he made eyes for himself out of that rosin.
Then he went away.

sentences.original: âhah kiya kâ-kisiwâhiyan, mahkêsîs, kâ-câh-câhkâpahôwin, kiwîh-ntonâtin.
sentences.english: “Now, as for you, Fox, who angered me by jabbing me in the eyes, I shall look for you.
When I find you, I shall kill you.”
Then he went from there.
He walked along.
Then at one time he heard a Sun-Dance going on.
He ran.
Whenever he listened, far off was the noise of the Sun-Dance.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah wâpahtam ostikwân êh-astêyik ôcêwah êh-tasîhkamiyit.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa wâpahtam ostikwân ê-astêyik ocêwa ê-tasîhkamiyit
sentences.english: At last he saw the head of an animal lying on the ground, with flies busy all over it.
He envied them for it.
“Little Brothers, I too shall be a fly,” he said to them.
sentences.footnote: LB on {nik-ôcân}:  The demoninative of {ocêw}: “fly”, is {ocêwiw}, used below; here the humorous formation is as though there were a primitive verb stem {ocâ-}: “to be a fly.”

sentences.english: “It is difficult.”
“Little Brothers, please let me be a fly.”
“It is difficult, Big Brother.”
“Little Brothers, please grant me what I beg.”
“Well then, let our older brother be a little one, a fly.”
“Oh dear, no,” said Wisahketchahk;
“I shall be very large; I shall be a big fly.”
“Oh, now, Big Brother, do please be small!” they asked him.
“Oh, very well!”
So he became a fly.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kwêskimôw; kâw âyîsiyiniwiw; pasikôw; misiwêw ostikwân oma sipwêhtatâw.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê kwêskîmow kâwi ayîsiyinîwiw pasikôw misiwê ostikwân ôma sipwêhtatâw
sentences.english: Suddenly he changed his form; he turned back into human shape; he arose; he carried off the whole head.
The deer's-head was fastened over his head.
So he went away.
He could not go fast.
He could not see at all, the way he was fixed.
After a while he was walking along the bank of a stream.
He fell and rolled.
The water carried him along in the river.
Soon the people saw him drifting along.
An old woman took an axe to kill him.
She went into the water to club the deer.
Wisahketchahk jumped to his feet; he ran away.
He fell where a big boulder lay; he smashed the head as he fell.
The old woman was chasing him.

sentences.original: êyakô mâka mînah wîsahkêcâhk! itwêw; pâhpiw.
sentences.english: “Why, it's Wisahketchahk again!” she said; she laughed.
Wisahketchahk ran away.
He stopped in his flight; then he again made off from that place.
As he walked along, he saw some geese.
The geese tried to get away.
“Wait a bit, Little Brothers!”
So they stopped.
He stepped up to them.
“Little Brothers, I too shall be a goose,” he said to them.
“It is difficult, Big Brother.”
At last he persuaded them.
He became a goose.

sentences.original: êkwah, nistêsê, ayîsiyiniwak wâpamatwâwi, ôhpimêh ka-pimihân, itêw.
sentences.english: “And now, Big Brother, whenever you see people, off to one side you will fly,” one said to him.
Then they ate, there in the lake.
Presently they flew up.
Wisahketchahk was in the lead.
He looked for people, just to be contrary.

sentences.original: piyisk miskawêw, tahkih cîk êkotah êh-pimihât.
sentences.text: piyisk miskawêw tahki cîki êkota ê-pimihât
sentences.english: At last he found them, and kept flying close to where they were.
The geese became worried; they fled.
But Wisahketchahk flew on in that place.
He began to be shot at.
When he made to flee, he burst the skin he had been given; down he went with a crash.
sentences.footnote: CHECK pitihkwaskamikisin. HCW:  Probably lexicon error.

sentences.english: An old woman saw him.
“There is Wisahketchahk again!” she said;
she laughed a great deal;
“It was Wisahketchahk we thought was a goose!” she said;
she laughed some more.
Then he went away from that place, too.
He was hungry; he had nothing to eat.
He decided to try and kill some game.

sentences.original: wâpamêw mostoswah nêwo; nama nânitaw isi kîh-nipahêw.
sentences.text: wâpamêw mostoswa nêwo nama nânitaw isi kî-nipahêw
sentences.english: He saw four buffalos; he had no way of killing them.
He walked about.

sentences.original: kêtahtawê oyahpitam mistikwah, ayîsiyiniwah êh-osîhât, tâpiskôc êh-mâsihitôwit;
sentences.text: kêtahtawê oyahpitam mistikwa ayîsiyiniwa ê-osîhât tâpiskôc ê-mâsihitoyit
sentences.english: Soon he tied up some sticks, arranging them like men wrestling;
then he went to where the buffalo were.
They started to run away.
“Wait, Little Brothers!” he called to them;

sentences.original: nêk âyîsiyiniwak kâ-mâsihitôcik, êh-twêt pêyak anah, êkwah kotak anah, êh-twit, êh-itwêt,
sentences.english: Those men are wrestling over there, because one of them said, 'Bulls stink,' and the other said, 'No. young steers are worse,'
that is the reason they are fighting;
but I have come to smell you.”
Then secretly he took his knife.

sentences.original: êkwah sîpâh ê-siniskêyit, ê-wîh-miyâmât takwâhnâwa, tahkamêw; npahêw.
sentences.text: êkwa sîpâ ê-isiniskêyit ê-wî-miyâmât takwahinâwa tahkamêw nipahêw
sentences.english: Then when he hold his arm out under the bull, to smell him, he stabbed him; he killed him.
He killed two of them.
“What's that nonsense about men fighting!
It's hungry I was!” said he.
He laughed a great deal.
“When I just made the thing, and there isn't any man there!”
Again he laughed.
“Now I shall eat a plenty.”
Then he skinned them.
And he prepared the meat.
When he had got it ready, he lay there.
“I shall eat later.
I shall eat a huge amount.”
He lay down between two trees.
“Straighten up, Little Brothers!”
At last he was tightly held by the trees.
Then he was entirely unable to get up from where he lay;
he was caught between the trees.
A young wolf came running up.
“Get out,” he said to him;
“You'll be inviting people, as usual, to dine on my meat,” he said to him.
The other began to eat.
All he could do was turn his head.
After a while the young wolf began to howl;

sentences.original: pikw îtêh ohci pâpahtâwak mahîhkanak mahkêsisak kîhkwahâkêsak, ahâsiwak mînah.
sentences.text: piko itê ohci pâpahtâwak mahîhkanak mahkêsîsak kîhkwahâhkêsak âhâsiwak mîna
sentences.english: from every direction they came running, wolves, foxes, coyotes, and crows.

sentences.original: êkwah wîsahkêcâhk owiyâsimah kahkiyaw maskahtôyiwah; ayis wiya micimôsôw mistikohk;
sentences.text: êkwa wîsahkêcâhk owiyâsima kahkiyaw maskahtoyiwa ayis wiya micimosow mistikohk
sentences.english: They scrambled for Wisahketchahk's meat and took it all; for he was caught between the trees;
and so he ate none of his meat.
Only after the others had made a clean sweep of it, did he get himself free.
Then he was angry.
He broke off four sticks;
he beat the trees that had held him fast.
“Now I regret it.”
Thus nothing at all did he eat of his buffalos;
the wolves had eaten them up.
Then he went away.
He saw some buffalo.
“Now I shall kill game.”
Then he stole up to them;
when he got near, he noisily broke wind.
They fled.
He got angry.
He stole up to another.

sentences.original: mwêhci minah kisiwâk êh-otihtât, kâ-misi-pwêkitot; osahamâk.
sentences.text: mwêhci mîna kisiwâk ê-otihtât kâ-misi-pwêkitot osahamâk
sentences.english: Again, just as he got near it, he loudly broke wind; it drove away his prey.
He went from there.
“In this you anger me, that you drive them away from me.
You will catch it!”
Then he looked for a stone.
He found a very large one.
Then he made a big fire.
He heated the stone; he heated it to a bright glow.
When he had got it to white heat, he took off his clothes.
Then he sat down on it.
He sizzled as he burned: “Hiss!” he sizzled.
“Why are you bound to cry out like that?
You drove off my game when I was going to bag it.”
Then, when he set out, he could not walk.
For a long time he wandered about.
Presently he found some berries; there were many of them.
Then he encountered one.
“Go easy, Brother,” it said to him;
“There are many bears here,” it told him.

sentences.original: êkwah osîhtamawin ahcâpiy êkwah acosisah êkwah môhkomân, napakihkomân, êkwah câpihcikanis;
sentences.english: “Then make me a bow, and arrows, and a knife, a bowie-knife, and a lance;
I shall hold these things in my hand.
I shall eat berries.
If I see a bear, I shall kill it.”
It made all these things for him.
Then he went and ate berries; he was armed.
Presently, while he was eating berries, a bear came running.

sentences.original: nakiskawêw; kêkwah otinêw ohcahcâpiyah mîna wîpisisah.
sentences.text: nakiskawêw kêkway otinêw ocahcâpiya mîna wîpisisa
sentences.english: He encountered it; he took his bow and his arrows.
He shot at it.
In the end he broke all his arrows as he shot them.
He struck it with his bow; it broke as he brought it down.

sentences.original: êkwah omôhkomân otinam; tahkamêw; pîkohtitâw omôhkomân.
sentences.text: êkwa omôhkomân otinam tahkamêw pîkohtitâw omôhkomân
sentences.english: Then he took his knife; he stabbed at the bear; he broke his knife with the thrust.
He threw it away.
Then he took his spear; when he landed it, it broke.
Then he fled to a big tree.
He ran round the tree.
The bear chased him round it.
He was almost dead for loss of breath.
Then at one time he struck with his foot and uncovered a skull, a buffalo-skull.
He knew that the other feared this object.
So in running past he grabbed it up and pulled it over his head.
He attacked the bear.
He drove it hard.
“Why must you be running away?
It's my turn to drive you hard;
you had me at close quarters, you know, Bear!”
And he laughed greatly as he drove fear into the bear.
Then he went away.

sentences.original: mâskôc kotak wâpamakih, nka-nipahik, itêyihtam êkwa wîsahkêcâhk.
sentences.english: “Perhaps if I see another one, it will kill me,” thought Wisahketchahk.
He went away; he tramped along.
He saw a house, a very ugly little house.
“I shall peek in through the door,” he thought.
He peeked in and saw a Windigo looking into a mirror.
Then whatever the other did, he did the same.
Then that Windigo said, “Really, I am handsome.
Really, I am throwing away my gifts, to be eating men.
I shall throw away my meat.”
So the Windigo threw away her supply of meat.
Then Wisahketchahk ran away.

sentences.original: êkwah awa wîhtikôw kahkiyaw ê-kîh-wêpinahk owiyâsimah, êkwah wâpamôw.
sentences.text: êkwa awa wîhtikôw kahkiyaw ê-kî-wêpinahk owiyâsima êkwa wâpamôw
sentences.english: Then, when the Windigo had thrown away all her stores of meat, then she looked into her mirror.
Her appearance was frightful.
“So this is Wisahketchahk again!
I will kill you, now I have ruined my meat.”
Then the Windigo went in pursuit.
Wisahketchahk was in mortal fright.
Now the other was close upon him; quickly she caught him.
And when she had caught him, “Gather sticks, Wisahketchahk!”
Then he gathered sticks.
Wisahketchahk wept as he went about, for now he was going to be killed.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-astamawât mihtah, êkwah wîhtikôw awa pônam.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-astamawât mihta êkwa wîhtikôw awa pônam
sentences.english: And when he placed the sticks for the Windigo, the latter built a fire with them.
“Go cut a spit for yourself!”
So he went off; he whimpered as he went about.
Then presently he saw a weasel.
“Come here, Little Brother!”

sentences.original: namoya; sâm kiwîh-nipahin, itik ôhi sihkosah.
sentences.english: “No; you mean to kill me,” the weasel answered him.
At last it came.
“Little Brother, a Windigo wants to kill me,” he told it;
“Try to do something or other to her.
I shall fix you so that you will be beautiful,” he, said to it.
“Very well,” said the weasel.
Then the weasel went to where the Windigo was.
It slipped into her mouth; it bit apart her heart.

sentences.original: êkwah awa wîhtikôw, kiyipah pêtâ kitapwânâsk! piyis nânitaw niwîh-is-âyân, êh-nôhtêhkatêyân, itik awa wîsahkêcâhk.
sentences.text: êkwa awa wîhtikôw itik awa wîsahkêcâhk
sentences.english: Then the Windigo, “Quickly bring your spit! What with all this delay, I am feeling queer from hunger,” she said to Wisahketchahk.
So he went there.
The other arose and came chasing him.
Then he fled, the other just managing to graze him with her claws.

sentences.original: misi-mâ-mawimôw, yêy yêh! êh-itwêt êôkô wîsahkêcâhk.
sentences.english: Loudly he lamented, crying, “Yeh ya!” that Wisahketchahk.
The Windigo was pressing close upon him.
But she died before she got him.
The weasel had killed her for him.
Then he took it up.
“Thank you, Little Brother.
That Windigo would certainly have killed me,” he said to it;
“And now, in winter you will be white;
your tail will have a little black at the tip.
And in summer you will be brown;
but your tail will be black in the same way.
And now I am leaving.”
Then he went away.
As he wandered along, presently he saw some people.
There was much pursuing.
He stayed there.
Then at one time a certain youth wanted to have a wife.
He disdained them all.
That young man was too conceited.
Then soon, Wisahketchahk made himself into a woman.
Handsome was this Wisahketchahk; he was very handsome.
Then he went to take as a husband that conceited young man.
He had two young wolves to draw his sled.
And they drew his tent.

sentences.original: êkwah ôw oskinîkiw miywêyimêw ôh ôskinîkiskwêwah.
sentences.text: êkwa awa oskinîkiw miywêyimêw ôhi oskinîkiskwêwa
sentences.english: And the young man took a liking to this young woman.
“Truly, she is handsome, Mother,” he told his mother;
“Do invite her,” he told her.
Then, “Yes,” said the old woman.
Then she went there.
“Niece, come to our house.”
“Ho,” said that Wisahketchahk, “What for?”
“Because my son wants to see you.”
Then, “Very well.”
“My son desires to marry you.”

sentences.original: mihcêt oskinîkiwak ê-nôhtê-wîkimicik êh-pê-tapasiyân, itêw, nistês, êh-isit.
sentences.english: “It is because so many young men wanted to marry me, that I ran away and came here,” he told her; “My elder brother having told me, 'Go away'.”

sentences.original: êkwah nôtokêsiw, niya mînah nikosis êh-pê-tapasît;
sentences.english: Then the old woman, “My son too ran away and came here;
because so many wanted to marry him is why he ran away and came here.”
“You don't say!” that woman answered her.
Then the other took her home.
She went to take that young man for her husband.
She saw the young man; he was very handsome.
She was married to him for a long time.
She was a very good worker.
At length, when she had been married to him for quite a while, she wanted to leave that place.
Then at one time she had babies, those wolf-cubs.
She tied up her babies.
She would not let her mother-in-law see them.

sentences.original: kêtahtawê nîpâtipisk sipwêhtêw êyôkô wîsahkêcâhk; cawâsimisah nakatêw.
sentences.text: kêtahtawê nîpâtipisk sipwêhtêw êwako wîsahkêcâhk ocawâsimisa nakatêw
sentences.english: Then one night Wisahketchahk departed; he left his babies behind.

sentences.original: êkwah nôtokêsiw êkwah kisêyiniw ntawi-wâpamêwak ôsisimiwâwah.
sentences.text: êkwa nôtokêsiw êkwa kisêyiniw nitawi-wâpamêwak ôsisimiwâwa
sentences.english: Then the old woman and the old man came to look at their grandchildren.
When they took them up, why, they were wolf-cubs.

sentences.original: êhêy, itwêw nôtokêsiw, wîsahkêcâhk ês ôyâh!
sentences.english: “Oho,” cried the old woman, “So that person was Wisahketchahk!”

sentences.original: pâhpiw mahîhkanisah kâ-tahkopitât, k-ôcawâsimisit êôkôh oskinîkiw ê-nêpêwisit.
sentences.text: pâhpiw mahîhkanisa kâ-tahkopitât kâ-ocawâsimisit êwako oskinîkiw ê-nêpêwisit
sentences.english: She laughed as she swaddled those wolf-puppies which the young man, to his great embarrassment, had for babies.
The other people laughed at him.

sentences.original: tâpwê mistahi isîhcikêw oskinîkiw, wîsahkêcâhkwah êh-wîwit!
sentences.english: “Truly, great things has this young man accomplished, in having Wisahketchahk for his wife!

sentences.original: êkwah ka-pâhpinânaw, êh-kihcêyimot oskinîkiw êh-wîwit wîci-nâpêwah wîsahkêcâhkwah.
sentences.english: Now we shall have something to laugh about, seeing that this conceited young man had Wisahketchahk, a man, as his wife!”
And they laughed a great deal.
He went away;

sentences.original: omis îtwêw : kiyâm pikw îs isinâkosici iskwêw nika-wîwin.
sentences.english: hus he spoke: “I don't care what sort of a looking woman I marry.
Wisahketchahk has put me to great shame,” he said.
Presently, as he wandered along, he saw a lodge.
He stood outside.

sentences.original: êkwah, pîhtokê, k-êtikot iskwêwah, kipê-wîwin, itêw.
sentences.english: Then, “Come in,” said the woman to him, “I have come to take you to wife,” he said to her.
When he entered, she was all round, like a ball.
Then he sat beside her; he took her to wife.
And she never went out at night.
And again he was ashamed, because he had that dumpy woman to wife.
They went away from there.
Early in the morning they made ready.
The woman had a bear as her beast of burden; she made it draw her sled.
The young man went home; he moved back home; he moved camp to his people's country.
When he arrived with his household, his wife rose to her feet.
She was no longer short and dumpy.
There was Wisahketchahk laughing.
“The proud young man had Wisahketchahk for his wife,” he said to him.
He had gone to meet him.
And he had married this other one too.
That is the end of this story.
